# Task

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.



# Special Instructions

None.

Here is the Julia code to solve this problem:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map(x -> Dates.year(x)*100 + Dates.month(x), df[:dt])
end
```
This function takes a DataFrame `df` as input and adds a new column `ym` to it. The values in this new column are the year and month of each DateTime value from the `dt` column, concatenated together into an integer format: "yyyymm". 

The `map()` function applies a function to every element in a collection (in this case, every row in the DataFrame). The function we're applying is `x -> Dates.year(x)*100 + Dates.month(x)`, which extracts the year and month from each DateTime value and combines them into an integer format "yyyymm". 

Please note that this code assumes that your DataFrame has a column named `dt` that contains DateTime values, and it will overwrite any existing columns with the same name. If you want to avoid overwriting existing columns, you can use a different name for the new column (e.g., `df[:ym] = map(x -> Dates.year(x)*100 + Dates.month(x), df[:dt])`).
